title: List homomorphism problems for signed trees1footnote 11footnote 1The first author received funding from the European Union’s Horizon 2020 project H2020-MSCA-RISE-2018: Research and Innovation Staff Exchange and from the Charles University Grant Agency project 1580119. The second author was supported by his NSERC Canada Discovery Grant. The fourth and fifth author were also partially supported by the fourth author’s NSERC Canada Discovery Grant. The fifth author was also supported by the Charles University Grant Agency project 1198419 and by the Czech Science Foundation (GA-ČR) project 19-17314J.

sections.basic facts:
We first mention the dichotomy classification of the problems S-Hom(H^)^𝐻(\widehat{H})
from [ref]8. A subgraph G^^𝐺\widehat{G} of the signed graph H^^𝐻\widehat{H} is the
s-core of H^^𝐻\widehat{H} if there is homomorphism f:H^→G^:𝑓→^𝐻^𝐺f:\widehat{H}\to\widehat{G}, and
every homomorphism G^→G^→^𝐺^𝐺\widehat{G}\to\widehat{G} is a bijection on V​(G)𝑉𝐺V(G). The letter s𝑠s stands
for signed. It is again easy to see that the s𝑠s-core is unique up to isomorphism and
switching equivalence. [ref]8
The problem S-Hom(H^)^𝐻(\widehat{H}) is polynomial-time solvable
if the s-core of H^^𝐻\widehat{H} has at most two edges, and is NP-complete otherwise. When the signature π𝜋\pi has all edges positive, the problem S-Hom(H,π)𝐻𝜋(H,\pi)
is equivalent to the unsigned graph homomorphism problem, and the s-core of (H,π)𝐻𝜋(H,\pi)
is just the core of H𝐻H. To compare Theorem 5 with the graph dichotomy
theorem of  as discussed at the beginning Section 1, we observe that
the core of a graph cannot have exactly two edges, as a core must be either a single vertex
(possibly with a loop), or a single edge, or a graph with at least three edges. Thus Theorem
5 is stronger than the graph dichotomy theorem from , which states
that the graph homomorphism problem to H𝐻H is polynomial-time solvable if the core of H𝐻H
has at most one edge and is NP-complete otherwise. (However, we note that the proof of
Theorem 5 in [ref]8 uses the graph dichotomy theorem .) Observe that an instance of the problem S-Hom​(H^)S-Hom^𝐻\textsc{S-Hom}(\widehat{H}) can be
also viewed as an instance of List-S-Hom​(H^)List-S-Hom^𝐻\textsc{List-S-Hom}(\widehat{H}) with all
lists L​(v)=V​(H)𝐿𝑣𝑉𝐻L(v)=V(H), therefore if S-Hom​(H^)S-Hom^𝐻\textsc{S-Hom}(\widehat{H}) is NP-complete,
then so is List-S-Hom​(H^)List-S-Hom^𝐻\textsc{List-S-Hom}(\widehat{H}). Moreover, if H^′superscript^𝐻′\widehat{H}^{\prime} is
an induced subgraph of H^^𝐻\widehat{H}, then any instance of
List-S-Hom​(H^′)List-S-Homsuperscript^𝐻′\textsc{List-S-Hom}(\widehat{H}^{\prime}) can be viewed as an instance of
List-S-Hom​(H^)List-S-Hom^𝐻\textsc{List-S-Hom}(\widehat{H}) (with the same lists), therefore if the
problem List-S-Hom​(H^′)List-S-Homsuperscript^𝐻′\textsc{List-S-Hom}(\widehat{H}^{\prime}) is NP-complete, then so is the
problem List-S-Hom​(H^)List-S-Hom^𝐻\textsc{List-S-Hom}(\widehat{H}). This yields the NP-completeness of
List-S-Hom​(H^)List-S-Hom^𝐻\textsc{List-S-Hom}(\widehat{H}) for all signed graphs (H^)^𝐻(\widehat{H}) that
contain an induced subgraph H^′superscript^𝐻′\widehat{H}^{\prime} whose s-core has more than two
edges. Furthermore, when the signed graph H^^𝐻\widehat{H} is uni-balanced, then we
may assume that all edges are at least blue, and the list homomorphism
problem for H𝐻H can be reduced to List-S-Hom​(H^)List-S-Hom^𝐻\textsc{List-S-Hom}(\widehat{H}). In particular,
we emphasize that List-S-Hom​(H^)List-S-Hom^𝐻\textsc{List-S-Hom}(\widehat{H}) is NP-complete if H^^𝐻\widehat{H}
is a uni-balanced signed graph (or, by a symmetric argument, an anti-uni-balanced signed
graph), and the underlying graph H𝐻H is not a bi-arc graph . Next we focus on the class of signed graphs that have no bicoloured loops and no bicoloured
edges. In this case, the following simple dichotomy describes the classification. (This result
was previously announced in .) It follows from our earlier remarks that these
signed graphs are balanced if and only if they are uni-balanced, and similarly they are anti-balanced
if and only if they are anti-uni-balanced. Suppose H^^𝐻\widehat{H} is a connected signed graph without bicoloured loops and edges.
If the underlying graph H𝐻H is a bi-arc graph, and H^^𝐻\widehat{H} is balanced or
anti-balanced, then the problem List-S-Hom​(H^)List-S-Hom^𝐻\textsc{List-S-Hom}(\widehat{H}) is polynomial-time
solvable. Otherwise, the problem is NP-complete. The polynomial cases follow from Feder et al. , by the following argument.
Suppose H^^𝐻\widehat{H} is balanced; we may assume all edges are blue. In ,
there is a polynomial-time algorithm to decide if the input signed graph G^^𝐺\widehat{G} is
balanced. If it is not balanced, there is no homomorphism of G^^𝐺\widehat{G} to H^^𝐻\widehat{H}.
Otherwise, we may assume that G^^𝐺\widehat{G} has also all edges blue and hence there is a
homomorphism of G^^𝐺\widehat{G} to H^^𝐻\widehat{H} if and only if there is a homomorphism of G𝐺G
to H𝐻H. Since H𝐻H is a bi-arc graph, this can be decided in polynomial time by the algorithm in
. The argument is similar if H^^𝐻\widehat{H} is anti-balanced. Otherwise, H^^𝐻\widehat{H}
contains a cycle which cannot be switched to a blue cycle and a cycle which cannot be switched
to a red cycle, in which case the s-core of H^^𝐻\widehat{H} contains at least three edges.
(This is true even if the cycles are just loops.)
\qed We have observed that List-S-Hom(H^)^𝐻(\widehat{H}) is NP-complete if the
s-core of H^^𝐻\widehat{H} has more than two edges. Thus we will focus on signed
graphs H^^𝐻\widehat{H} whose s-cores have at most two edges. This is not as simple
as it sounds, as there are many complex signed graphs with this property, including,
for example, all irreflexive bipartite signed graphs that contain a bicoloured edge,
and all signed graphs that contain a bicoloured loop. That these cases are not easy
underlines the fact that the assumptions in Theorem 6 cannot be
weakened without significant new breakthroughs. Consider, for example, allowing
bicoloured edges but not bicoloured loops. In this situation, we may focus on the
case when there is a bicoloured edge (else Theorem 6 applies),
and so if there is any loop at all, the s-core would have more than two edges. Thus
we consider irreflexive signed graphs. The s-core is still too big if the underlying
graph has an odd cycle. So in this case it remains to classify the irreflexive bipartite
signed graphs that contain a bicoloured edge. Even this case is complex. We explore
homomorphisms to irreflexive bipartite signed graphs in a companion paper. In this paper we focus on List-S-Hom​(H^)List-S-Hom^𝐻\textsc{List-S-Hom}(\widehat{H}) when the underlying
graph of H^^𝐻\widehat{H} is a tree with possible loops. We have treated the special cases
of reflexive and irreflexive trees in  and in the conference version of this paper ;
in the general case presented here, the polynomial algorithms are much more involved
and technical, and the structure of these trees turns out to be surprisingly complex.
Nevertheless, they seem to suggest that nice characterizations may be possible, in
analogy to bi-arc trees , see also . We now introduce our basic tool for proving NP-completeness. Let (U,D)𝑈𝐷(U,D) be two walks in H^^𝐻\widehat{H} of equal length, say U𝑈U, with
vertices u=u0,u1,…,uk=vformulae-sequence𝑢subscript𝑢0subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢𝑘𝑣u=u_{0},u_{1},\ldots,u_{k}=v and D𝐷D, with vertices u=d0,d1,…,dk=vformulae-sequence𝑢subscript𝑑0subscript𝑑1…subscript𝑑𝑘𝑣u=d_{0},d_{1},\ldots,d_{k}=v. We say that (U,D)𝑈𝐷(U,D) is a chain, provided u​u1,dk−1​v𝑢subscript𝑢1subscript𝑑𝑘1𝑣uu_{1},d_{k-1}v are unicoloured edges and u​d1,uk−1​v𝑢subscript𝑑1subscript𝑢𝑘1𝑣ud_{1},u_{k-1}v are bicoloured edges, and
for each i𝑖i, 1≤i≤k−21𝑖𝑘21\leq i\leq k-2, we have both ui​ui+1subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖1u_{i}u_{i+1} and di​di+1subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖1d_{i}d_{i+1} are edges of H^^𝐻\widehat{H}
while di​ui+1subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖1d_{i}u_{i+1} is not an edge of H^^𝐻\widehat{H}, or both ui​ui+1subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖1u_{i}u_{i+1} and di​di+1subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖1d_{i}d_{i+1} are bicoloured edges of H^^𝐻\widehat{H}
while di​ui+1subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖1d_{i}u_{i+1} is not a bicoloured edge of H^^𝐻\widehat{H}. If a signed graph H^^𝐻\widehat{H} contains a chain, then
List-S-Hom​(H^)List-S-Hom^𝐻\textsc{List-S-Hom}(\widehat{H}) is NP-complete. Suppose that H^^𝐻\widehat{H} has a chain (U,D)𝑈𝐷(U,D) as specified above. We shall
reduce from Not-All-Equal SAT. (Each clause has three unnegated
variables, and we seek a truth assignment in which at least one variable is
true and at least one is false, in each clause.) For each clause x∨y∨z𝑥𝑦𝑧x\lor y\lor z, we take three vertices x,y,z𝑥𝑦𝑧x,y,z, each with list {u}𝑢\{u\}, and three
vertices x′,y′,z′superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′superscript𝑧′x^{\prime},y^{\prime},z^{\prime}, each with list {v}𝑣\{v\}. For the triple x,y,z𝑥𝑦𝑧x,y,z, we add
three new vertices p​(x,y)𝑝𝑥𝑦p(x,y), p​(y,z)𝑝𝑦𝑧p(y,z), and p​(z,x)𝑝𝑧𝑥p(z,x), each with list
{u1,d1}subscript𝑢1subscript𝑑1\{u_{1},d_{1}\}, and for the triple x′,y′,z′superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′superscript𝑧′x^{\prime},y^{\prime},z^{\prime}, we add three new vertices
p​(x′,y′),p​(y′,z′),p​(z′,x′)𝑝superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′𝑝superscript𝑦′superscript𝑧′𝑝superscript𝑧′superscript𝑥′p(x^{\prime},y^{\prime}),p(y^{\prime},z^{\prime}),p(z^{\prime},x^{\prime}), each with list {uk−1,dk−1}subscript𝑢𝑘1subscript𝑑𝑘1\{u_{k-1},d_{k-1}\}. We
connect these vertices as follows: p​(x,y)𝑝𝑥𝑦p(x,y) adjacent to x𝑥x by a red edge and to y𝑦y by a blue edge, p​(y,z)𝑝𝑦𝑧p(y,z) adjacent to y𝑦y by a red edge and to z𝑧z by a blue edge, p​(z,x)𝑝𝑧𝑥p(z,x) adjacent to z𝑧z by a red edge and to x𝑥x by a blue edge. Analogously, the hexagon x′,p​(x′,y′),y′,p​(y′,z′),z′,p​(z′,x′)superscript𝑥′𝑝superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′superscript𝑦′𝑝superscript𝑦′superscript𝑧′superscript𝑧′𝑝superscript𝑧′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime},p(x^{\prime},y^{\prime}),y^{\prime},p(y^{\prime},z^{\prime}),z^{\prime},p(z^{\prime},x^{\prime}) will also
be alternating in blue and red colours, with (say) p​(x′,y′)𝑝superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′p(x^{\prime},y^{\prime}) adjacent to x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime}
by a red edge. Moreover, we join each pair of vertices p​(x,y)𝑝𝑥𝑦p(x,y) and p​(x′,y′)𝑝superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′p(x^{\prime},y^{\prime}) by a separate
path P​(x,y)𝑃𝑥𝑦P(x,y) with k−1𝑘1k-1 vertices, say p​(x,y)=a1,a2,…,ak−2,ak−1=p​(x′,y′)formulae-sequence𝑝𝑥𝑦subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2…subscript𝑎𝑘2subscript𝑎𝑘1𝑝superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′p(x,y)=a_{1},a_{2},\ldots,a_{k-2},a_{k-1}=p(x^{\prime},y^{\prime}), where aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} has list {ui,di}subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖\{u_{i},d_{i}\} and the edge
ai​ai+1subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖1a_{i}a_{i+1} is blue unless both ui​ui+1subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖1u_{i}u_{i+1} and di​di+1subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖1d_{i}d_{i+1} are bicoloured,
in which case ai​ai+1subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖1a_{i}a_{i+1} is also bicoloured. Paths P​(z,x)𝑃𝑧𝑥P(z,x) and P​(y,z)𝑃𝑦𝑧P(y,z) are
defined analogously. See Figure 1 for an illustration. We observe for future reference that the path x,p​(x,y)=a1,a2,…,ak−2,formulae-sequence𝑥𝑝𝑥𝑦subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2…subscript𝑎𝑘2x,p(x,y)=a_{1},a_{2},\ldots,a_{k-2}, ak−1=p​(x′,y′),x′subscript𝑎𝑘1𝑝superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′superscript𝑥′a_{k-1}=p(x^{\prime},y^{\prime}),x^{\prime}, when considered by itself, admits a list
homomorphism both to U𝑈U and to D𝐷D. (To see this invoke Zaslavsky’s theorem
characterizing switching equivalent signatures, and use the fact that both
U𝑈U and D𝐷D contain a bicoloured edge.) Further we note there is no list
homomorphism to any other subgraph of U∪D𝑈𝐷U\cup D where p​(x,y)𝑝𝑥𝑦p(x,y) maps
to d1subscript𝑑1d_{1} and p​(x′,y′)𝑝superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′p(x^{\prime},y^{\prime}) maps to uk−1subscript𝑢𝑘1u_{k-1}. (This follows from the conditions
in the definition of chain.) If x𝑥x occurs in several clauses, we now have several vertices corresponding
to x𝑥x. We link all these occurrences by a new vertex p​(x)𝑝𝑥p(x) with the list {u1}subscript𝑢1\{u_{1}\},
and joined by blue edges to all the occurrences of x𝑥x. Since the edge
u​u1𝑢subscript𝑢1uu_{1} is unicoloured, this will ensure that all occurrences of the vertex x𝑥x are
switched or no occurrence of x𝑥x is switched. We denote the resulting graph (G,σ)𝐺𝜎(G,\sigma). We now claim that this instance of
Not-All-Equal SAT is satisfiable if and only if (G,σ)𝐺𝜎(G,\sigma)
admits a list homomorphism to (H,π)𝐻𝜋(H,\pi). Let G^​(x,y,z)^𝐺𝑥𝑦𝑧\widehat{G}(x,y,z) denote the subgraph of (G,σ)𝐺𝜎(G,\sigma) induced by
P​(x,y),P​(z,x),P​(y,z)𝑃𝑥𝑦𝑃𝑧𝑥𝑃𝑦𝑧P(x,y),P(z,x),P(y,z) and x,y,z,x′,y′,z′𝑥𝑦𝑧superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′superscript𝑧′x,y,z,x^{\prime},y^{\prime},z^{\prime}. We claim that
(i)
any list homomorphism of G^​(x,y,z)^𝐺𝑥𝑦𝑧\widehat{G}(x,y,z) to U∪D𝑈𝐷U\cup D must switch at
either one or two of the vertices x,y,z𝑥𝑦𝑧x,y,z, and that 
(ii) there are
list homomorphisms of G^​(x,y,z)^𝐺𝑥𝑦𝑧\widehat{G}(x,y,z) to U∪D𝑈𝐷U\cup D that switch at any
one or any two of the vertices x,y,z𝑥𝑦𝑧x,y,z. Once this claim is proved, we can associate with every truth assignment a list
homomorphism of G^​(x,y,z)^𝐺𝑥𝑦𝑧\widehat{G}(x,y,z) to U∪D𝑈𝐷U\cup D where a vertex
corresponding to a variable is switched if and only if that variable is true,
and conversely, setting a variable true if its corresponding vertex was
switched in the list homomorphism.
Since we have ensured that all occurrences of a variable are switched or all
are not switched, we conclude that all occurrences of a variable take on the
same truth value. We now prove (i). Since the lists are so restrictive, any list homomorphism is
fully described by what happens to the paths P​(x,y)𝑃𝑥𝑦P(x,y), P​(z,x)𝑃𝑧𝑥P(z,x), P​(y,z)𝑃𝑦𝑧P(y,z),
and whether or not the vertices corresponding to x,y,z𝑥𝑦𝑧x,y,z (and x′,y′,z′superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′superscript𝑧′x^{\prime},y^{\prime},z^{\prime})
are switched. Note that U𝑈U begins with a unicoloured edge and D𝐷D ends with a
unicoloured edge. If neither x𝑥x nor y𝑦y or both x𝑥x and y𝑦y
are switched, the edges x​p​(x,y)𝑥𝑝𝑥𝑦xp(x,y) and p​(x,y)​y𝑝𝑥𝑦𝑦p(x,y)y are different colours, and
in any list homomorphism of G^​(x,y,z)^𝐺𝑥𝑦𝑧\widehat{G}(x,y,z) to U∪D𝑈𝐷U\cup D we must map
P​(x,y)𝑃𝑥𝑦P(x,y) to D𝐷D. In particular, x′​p​(x′,y′)superscript𝑥′𝑝superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′x^{\prime}p(x^{\prime},y^{\prime}) and p​(x′,y′)​y′𝑝superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′superscript𝑦′p(x^{\prime},y^{\prime})y^{\prime} map to a unicoloured
edge and must have the same colour. Thus, if none or all of the vertices x,y,z𝑥𝑦𝑧x,y,z
were switched, then the hexagon x′,p​(x′,y′),y′,p​(y′,z′),z′,p​(z′,x′)superscript𝑥′𝑝superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′superscript𝑦′𝑝superscript𝑦′superscript𝑧′superscript𝑧′𝑝superscript𝑧′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime},p(x^{\prime},y^{\prime}),y^{\prime},p(y^{\prime},z^{\prime}),z^{\prime},p(z^{\prime},x^{\prime}) has an
even number of red and even number of blue edges, which is impossible. (It
started with an odd number of each.) For (ii), it remains to show that one or two of the vertices x,y,z𝑥𝑦𝑧x,y,z can be
switched under a list homomorphism of G^​(x,y,z)^𝐺𝑥𝑦𝑧\widehat{G}(x,y,z) to U∪D𝑈𝐷U\cup D. Suppose
first that only one was switched; by symmetry assume it was x𝑥x (so y𝑦y and
z𝑧z were not switched). Now edges x,p​(x,y)𝑥𝑝𝑥𝑦x,p(x,y) and p​(x,y),y𝑝𝑥𝑦𝑦p(x,y),y have the same
colour, and z,p​(z,x)𝑧𝑝𝑧𝑥z,p(z,x) and p​(z,x),x𝑝𝑧𝑥𝑥p(z,x),x have the same colour. By the above
observation, we can map P​(x,y)𝑃𝑥𝑦P(x,y) and P​(z,x)𝑃𝑧𝑥P(z,x) to U𝑈U, and map P​(y,z)𝑃𝑦𝑧P(y,z) to D𝐷D.
Note that the switchings necessary for these list homomorphisms affect
disjoint sets of vertices (the paths P​(x,y),P​(y,z),P​(z,x)𝑃𝑥𝑦𝑃𝑦𝑧𝑃𝑧𝑥P(x,y),P(y,z),P(z,x)), so the
observation applies. If two vertices, say y𝑦y and z𝑧z were switched, the
argument is almost the same and we omit it.
\qed
